Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Role of School Context and Parenting on Racial Neighborhood Sorting

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Choosing where to live involves an array of potentially important factors, from housing size, quality and cost to various local neighborhood characteristics, amenities and municipal services. Prior research has shown that what matters most varies over individuals' lifetimes, and that families raising children are particularly attentive to local schooling conditions. This project applies these prior insights to understand neighborhood racial segregation in the post-Civil Rights era, analyzing how local school racial diversity and mandated school racial desegregation policies influence where white and black families choose to live and why they move.

The project is designed as a statistical analysis of the Panel Study of Income Dynamics, which has followed a nationally representative sample of white and black families nearly every year from 1968-2011. Family residential location year-by-year is analyzed with a focus on how the residential choices of adults raising young and school-aged children differ from adults who do not have child caretaking responsibilities. A range of neighborhood-level demographic data from the U.S. Census is used to contextualize these decisions. In addition, the project uses geographic software to link housing location to educational context, including local school racial composition and district desegregation policy as well as per pupil expenditures, average class size, and, in more recent years, school-wide reading and math test proficiency levels. The project will evaluate the relative importance of school racial composition on the discrete housing choices of families with children weighed against the various non-racial factors that inform these decisions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Sociology Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant #1519017 supported the successful completion of a student dissertation project evaluating how policies and local school context shapes parental decisions about where to live and send their children to school. NSF funding was used to access school standardized test performance data through a licensing agreement with greatschools.org. School test score data were incorporated into a statistical analysis evaluating how choices about where to live vary by household race and parental status. The actual residential moves of a national sample of black and white households were followed between 1997 and 2011, with each choice of where to live (and where not to live) mapped onto local social, economic, geographic, and educational characteristics.

 

The study showed that white parents are more likely than white non-parents to sort into neighborhoods with mostly white or all white student populations. This racial sorting pattern persists even after accounting for home-ownership status and a range of local characteristics, including housing size and affordability, median neighborhood income, unemployment, poverty, and proximity to commercial centers. In contrast, black households show little variation in racial neighborhood sorting by parental status, and generally move into destinations with racially integrated rather than all-black or mostly-black schools. Crucially, the inclusion of local school information into the statistical models shows virtually no change in patterns of racial sorting. That is, various school factors—peer poverty composition, average class size, district per pupil funding, and academic achievement on standardized exams—fail to explain white parents’ distinct inclination toward neighborhoods with segregated white public schools. These findings link the persistence of racial segregation to white parental agency in the housing market.

 

The project generated intellectual merit by documenting white parental agency in housing markets as a contributing factor of residential and educational segregation. The results were presented in detail in the first chapter of the dissertation. In the second chapter, supplementary analysis of historical residential mobility show evidence of white avoidance of neighborhoods experiencing mandated school district desegregation between 1968 and 1990. White non-parents had weaker policy avoidance tendencies, and black parents and non-parents showed no avoidance of school desegregation. Finally, a third chapter shows that in a contemporary, high-minority, high-poverty school district, parents with the most available economic resources are the most likely to act upon new information about school quality, while those with fewer resources are left behind in areas where low performing schools cluster. The dissertation’s overall empirical contribution—documenting parental attention to schools as a social force contributing to racial and socioeconomic inequality—bridges together important prior work from the Social Stratification, Sociology of Education, Race and Ethnicity, and Urban Sociology subfields.

 

The dissertation has broader impacts for society, showing that school choice policies in an open market are vulnerable to the dynamic sorting behavior of parents. Parents are well within their rights to maximize resources for their children, but the evidence produced in this dissertation research shows that this form of parental agency—if unregulated—can in fact undermine educational policies attempting to racially integrate schools or expand educational access.
